thread.title: Court Hears Arguments on Trump Travel Ban: Live Analysis
thread.title_full: Court Hears Arguments on Trump Travel Ban: Live Analysis

title: Court Hears Arguments on Trump Travel Ban: Live Analysis
text:
Search SEARCH → BROWSER UPDATE To gain access to the full experience, please upgrade your browser: Chrome | Safari | Firefox | Internet Explorer Note: If you are running Internet Explorer 10 and above, make sure it is not in compatibility mode. Recap Court Hears Arguments on Trump Travel Ban: Live Analysis Last Updated Feb 7, 2017 at 7:59 pm ET 
The Justice Department asked an appeals court to reverse a lower-court order barring travel-ban enforcement. The oral arguments have concluded. SHARE 
This Concludes Our Live Coverage 
Bottom Line: No Simple Win Tonight for Either Side 
Trump Administration Lawyer: Court Mustn't Enjoin Security Decision 'Based on Some Newspaper Articles' 
Another Telling Exchange: Judge Notes Few Muslims Affected 
Arguments End 
Purcell Wraps Up, Flentje Rebuts See only Highlights Highlights This Concludes Our Live Coverage 
This concludes our live coverage -- thank you for reading. You can check out our updated main story below: Twitter Analysis Judges Sought Answers From Both Sides on Whether the Ban Was -- or Wasn't -- Motivated by Anti-Muslim Bias 
The appeals court judges also pressed Mr. Flentje to explain why the executive order should not be considered a violation of constitutional protections against religious discrimination. 
“Could the president simply say in the order we’re not going to let any Muslims in?’’ asked Judge William Canby. 
“That’s not what the order does,’’ Mr. Flentje replied. "This is a far cry from that situation.’’ 
At one point, Mr. Flentje was scrambling to answer the judges’ questions, saying, “I’m not sure I’m convincing the court.’’ 
Another judge on the panel, Richard Clifton, voiced skepticism about claims the executive order was discriminatory. He pressed a lawyer for the state of Washington, which filed the lawsuit against the government, to explain why the president would not have the authority to bar people from countries that pose a significant risk of terrorism. 
“I have trouble understanding why we’re supposed to infer religious animus,’’ said Judge Clifton. “The concern for terrorism with those connected to radical Islamic sects is kind of hard to deny.’’ 
Mr. Purcell answered that by the president’s own statements, and those of some of his advisers, the executive order grew out of a desire to keep Muslims out of the country. 
“At this point it’s now the federal government that’s asking the courts to upset the status quo,’’ Mr. Purcell said. “Things are slowly returning to normal before the chaos of the executive order.’’ Devlin Barrett
